title: Accelerating Clean Energy Transition: Policy Options for Grid Modernization
authors:
Energy Policy Institute
Authors: Michael Torres, Jennifer Liu, Robert Park

paragraphs.text: The U.S. electrical grid requires urgent modernization to accommodate renewable energy sources and meet climate targets. Current infrastructure, designed for centralized fossil fuel generation, cannot efficiently integrate distributed renewables or manage bidirectional power flows.

sentences.text: The U.S. electrical grid requires urgent modernization to accommodate renewable energy sources and meet climate targets.
Current infrastructure, designed for centralized fossil fuel generation, cannot efficiently integrate distributed renewables or manage bidirectional power flows.

paragraphs.text: Key findings: • Grid congestion costs consumers $13.7 billion annually • 30% of renewable projects face multi-year interconnection delays • Smart grid investments could reduce emissions by 18% by 2030

sentences.text: Key findings: • Grid congestion costs consumers $13.7 billion annually • 30% of renewable projects face multi-year interconnection delays • Smart grid investments could reduce emissions by 18% by 2030

paragraphs.text: We propose three policy pathways: regulatory reform to streamline permitting, federal funding for grid storage, and regional transmission planning mandates. Implementation requires $75-100 billion over 10 years but generates $250 billion in economic benefits.

sentences.text: We propose three policy pathways: regulatory reform to streamline permitting, federal funding for grid storage, and regional transmission planning mandates.

paragraphs.text: The American electrical grid, built primarily between 1950-1980, faces unprecedented challenges. Renewable energy capacity has grown 400% since 2010, yet transmission capacity increased only 23%. This mismatch creates bottlenecks that strand clean energy in rural areas while urban centers rely on fossil fuels.

paragraphs.text: Recent extreme weather events exposed grid vulnerabilities. The 2021 Texas freeze caused 246 deaths and $195 billion in damages. California's rolling blackouts affected 800,000 customers during heatwaves. Climate change will intensify these stresses.

paragraphs.text: Federal infrastructure legislation allocated $65 billion for grid improvements, but deployment faces regulatory barriers. States control siting decisions, creating a patchwork of conflicting requirements. Interstate transmission projects average 10-15 years from proposal to operation.

paragraphs.text: Three structural barriers impede grid modernization:

sentences.text: Three structural barriers impede grid modernization:

paragraphs.text: 1. Regulatory fragmentation: Federal (FERC), state (PUCs), and local authorities have overlapping jurisdiction. No single entity can approve interstate transmission lines. This creates veto points where individual states block projects benefiting neighboring regions.

sentences.text: 1. Regulatory fragmentation: Federal (FERC), state (PUCs), and local authorities have overlapping jurisdiction.
No single entity can approve interstate transmission lines.
This creates veto points where individual states block projects benefiting neighboring regions.

paragraphs.text: 2. Cost allocation disputes: Who pays for transmission upgrades when benefits cross state lines? Current methods socialize costs locally while benefits accrue regionally, creating perverse incentives against infrastructure investment.

sentences.text: 2. Cost allocation disputes: Who pays for transmission upgrades when benefits cross state lines?
Current methods socialize costs locally while benefits accrue regionally, creating perverse incentives against infrastructure investment.

paragraphs.text: 3. Technology gaps: Existing grid infrastructure lacks sensors, automation, and storage needed for renewable integration. Wind and solar variability requires real-time balancing impossible with analog systems.

sentences.text: 3. Technology gaps: Existing grid infrastructure lacks sensors, automation, and storage needed for renewable integration.
Wind and solar variability requires real-time balancing impossible with analog systems.

paragraphs.text: Market failures compound these issues. Transmission owners earn regulated returns on capital investments, incentivizing expensive projects over efficient operations. Meanwhile, renewable developers face unpredictable interconnection costs ranging from $10,000 to $10 million per project.

paragraphs.text: Option 1: Federal Transmission Planning Authority

sentences.text: Option 1: Federal Transmission Planning Authority

paragraphs.text: Create federal authority to designate transmission corridors and override state objections for projects meeting national interest criteria. Model on Natural Gas Act authority.

paragraphs.text: Pros: Breaks deadlock on critical projects, enables long-term planning Cons: State opposition, potential constitutional challenges, 3-5 year implementation

paragraphs.text: Option 2: Grid Investment Tax Credits Expand Investment Tax Credit (ITC) to cover transmission and storage infrastructure. Provide 30% credit for qualifying projects.

paragraphs.text: We recommend a hybrid approach combining federal backstop authority with financial incentives:

sentences.text: We recommend a hybrid approach combining federal backstop authority with financial incentives:

paragraphs.text: 1. Immediate actions (0-2 years): - Expand ITC to transmission/storage with bonus for interregional projects - Streamline NEPA reviews for transmission using categorical exclusions - DOE fund state planning grants conditioned on regional cooperation

sentences.text: 1. Immediate actions (0-2 years): - Expand ITC to transmission/storage with bonus for interregional projects - Streamline NEPA reviews for transmission using categorical exclusions - DOE fund state planning grants conditioned on regional cooperation

paragraphs.text: 2. Medium-term reforms (2-5 years): - Establish Federal Transmission Planning Authority with narrow scope - Implement minimum transfer capability requirements between regions - Create federal cost allocation methodology for interstate projects

sentences.text: 2. Medium-term reforms (2-5 years): - Establish Federal Transmission Planning Authority with narrow scope - Implement minimum transfer capability requirements between regions - Create federal cost allocation methodology for interstate projects

paragraphs.text: 3. Long-term transformation (5-10 years): - Universal RTO participation with performance incentives - Deploy national grid monitoring system with AI optimization - Develop continental SuperGrid connecting all regions
